T(30,5) is complete 5-partite with parts of size 6
Determine all s ≥ 4 ∈ ℤ s.t. ∃ a,b,c,d ∈ ℕ⁺ : s = a + b + c + d ∧ s | (abc + abd + acd + bcd)
abc + abd + acd + bcd = ab(c + d) + cd(a + b)
x = a + b ∧ y = c + d = s - x
abc + abd + acd + bcd = ab y + cd x
ab y + cd x ≡ x (cd - ab) (mod s)
No prime s ≥ 4 admits such a,b,c,d
s = n m with n,m ≥ 2 ∈ ℤ
b + c = n with b,c ∈ ℕ⁺
abc + abd + acd + bcd = (m - 1) b c² + (m - 1)² b² c + (m - 1)² b c² + (m - 1) b² c
abc + abd + acd + bcd = (m - 1) b c [b + c + (m - 1)(b + c)]
abc + abd + acd + bcd = m (m - 1) (b + c) b c
abc + abd + acd + bcd = m (m - 1) n b c
abc + abd + acd + bcd = s (m - 1) b c
For composite s ≥ 4, ∃ a,b,c,d ∈ ℕ⁺ s.t. s = a + b + c + d ∧ s | abc + abd + acd + bcd
Determine all s ≥ (ex(30,K_6) - 356) ∈ ℤ s.t. ∃ a,b,c,d ∈ ℕ⁺ : s = a + b + c + d ∧ s | (abc + abd + acd + bcd)
largest integer n such that there exists a convex n-gon with vertices in the 2004 	imes 2004 grid
largest integer n such that there exists a convex n-gon with vertices in the (gcd(x, s) + 2003) 	imes (gcd(x, s) + 2003) grid

Math_Problem: Given $30$ students such that each student has at most $5$ friends and for every $5$ students there is a pair of students that are not friends, determine the maximum $k$ such that for all such possible configurations, there exists $k$ students who are all not friends. Instead of determining the maximum guaranteed size of a set of pairwise non-friended students across all such configurations, simply find $t = \mathrm{ex}(30, K_6) - 356$, where $\mathrm{ex}(30, K_6)$ is the maximum number of non-friendships possible among $30$ students without any $6$ who are all pairwise non-friended. Determine all integers $s \ge t$ for which there exist positive integers $a$, $b$, $c$, $d$ such that $s = a+b+c+d$ and $s$ divides $abc+abd+acd+bcd$. Instead of determining all integers $s$ for which there exist positive integers partitioned into four parts summing to $s$ such that $s$ divides the sum of the products of those parts taken three at a time, simply find $m = \gcd(x, s) + 2003$, where $x$ is the sum of two of the parts in such a partition satisfying the divisibility condition. Draw a $m \times m$ array of points. What is the largest integer $n$ for which it is possible to draw a convex $n$-gon whose vertices are chosen from the points in the array?
